question_details.title: Will the US Steel/Nippon Steel merger collapse before April 1, 2025?
question_details.description: Wikipedia: [Proposed acquisition of U.S. Steel by Nippon Steel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proposed_acquisition_of_U.S._Steel_by_Nippon_Steel)
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before April 1, 2025, either U.S. Steel or Nippon Steel files an SEC Form 8-K announcing the merger agreement's termination or abandonment.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Ancora Urges U.S. Steel's Board of Directors to Delay the 2025 A**
Ancora Holdings Group, LLC, a shareholder of United States Steel Corporation, has written a letter to the company's Board of Directors urging them to delay the 2025 Annual Meeting due to the uncertainty surrounding the blocked sale to Nippon Steel Corporation. Ancora has nominated nine highly qualified candidates for election to the Board, including industry legend Alan Kestenbaum, who is prepared to step into the CEO role to turn the company's operations around. The company believes that it would be unfair to hold the Annual Meeting during a period of self-manufactured uncertainty and is urging the Board to delay it by at least 45 days following the June 18 outside date for unwinding the merger agreement.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 27, 2025 10:16 PM
Source:[GuruFocus](https://www.gurufocus.com/news/2720293/ancora-urges-us-steels-board-of-directors-to-delay-the-2025-annual-meeting-of-stockholders)

**Ancora Urges U.S. Steel's Board of Directors to Delay the 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders**
Ancora Holdings Group, LLC, a shareholder of United States Steel Corporation, has written a letter to the company's Board of Directors urging them to delay the 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders. The letter, signed by Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Fredrick D. DiSanto, argues that holding the meeting during a period of uncertainty related to the blocked sale to Nippon Steel Corporation would be an 'entrenchment maneuver'. Ancora has nominated nine highly qualified and independent candidates for election to the Board, including industry legend Alan Kestenbaum, who is prepared to step into the Chief Executive Officer role to turn the operations of the Company around. The letter states that shareholders deserve to know the outcome of the Company's 'Hail Mary' litigation before casting their vote, and that delaying the meeting by at least 45 days following the June 18th outside date for unwinding the merger agreement is warranted and appropriate. 'Seeking to hold the Annual Meeting during this period of extraordinary uncertainty while pursuing a blocked deal in defiance of a former president's executive order and a current president's stated opposition would represent a self-serving entrenchment tactic,' the letter says. 'We hope you will make the right decision to delay the Annual Meeting.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 27, 2025 09:30 PM
Source:[Business Wire](https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20250227867016/en/Ancora-Urges-U.S.-Steel%E2%80%99s-Board-of-Directors-to-Delay-the-2025-Annual-Meeting-of-Stockholders)

**Nippon Steel's US Steel Acquisition Plan Sparks Tension with Trump Administration**
After the US-Japan summit, US President Trump reiterated that Japanese steelmaker Nippon Steel cannot acquire a majority stake in US Steel. However, Nippon Steel's first official statement after a two-week silence differed from Trump's stance. Nippon Steel's President Imai said, 'Investment and equipment investment cannot be separated. Only by investing can we make a large-scale investment decision.' He also emphasized that the US-Japan negotiations started with the original contract to merge US Steel and Nippon Steel. Nippon Steel reaffirmed its plan to acquire US Steel and make it a fully-owned subsidiary. While discussing with the US government to explain the situation to Trump, Nippon Steel's Vice President visited the US on the 12th, but the meeting schedule with Trump's team has not been confirmed. Nippon Steel has repeatedly emphasized its intention to maintain its original stance, making the US Steel-related negotiations with the Trump administration seem inevitable to be difficult.
Original language: ko
Publish date: February 27, 2025 01:56 AM
Source:[YTN](https://www.ytn.co.kr/_ln/0134_202502270906237108)

**Nippon Steel Doubles Down on $14.1-B US Steel Pursuit**
Nippon Steel remains committed to acquiring US Steel (NYSE: X) for $14.1 billion, despite facing political resistance and shifting statements from the White House. Nippon Steel President Tadashi Imai stated, 'The starting point for our discussions with the US government will be this merger agreement.' The acquisition was blocked by former President Joe Biden in January, citing national security concerns, and President Donald Trump has echoed similar reservations. Nippon Steel has rejected claims of potential conflicts with US interests as 'littered with factual inaccuracies and omissions.' The proposed takeover may be on the agenda for Japanese Trade Minister Yoji Muto's visit to the US in March. Meanwhile, the renewed tariff threat from Trump is causing uncertainty for steel imports from Canada and Mexico, potentially affecting North American supply chains and steel prices.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 03:50 PM
Source:[thedeepdive.ca](https://thedeepdive.ca/nippon-steel-doubles-down-on-14-1-b-us-steel-pursuit/)

**US Steelworkers Union Files Complaint Over Nippon Steel Acquisition Plan**
The United Steelworkers (USW) labor union has filed a complaint with the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) against Nippon Steel's plan to acquire US Steel, alleging that the company has been pressuring union members to silence opposition to the deal. According to the USW, US Steel has repeatedly attacked the union to weaken it, making it impossible for members to express their opposition to the plan. The union also claims that US Steel's CEO, David Burritt, threatened to withhold funding for union facilities if the deal did not go through. The USW has consistently opposed the acquisition plan since it was announced in December 2024. The union is seeking an injunction to stop Nippon Steel and US Steel from blocking the acquisition and undermining US Steel's competitiveness.
Original language: ja
Publish date: February 26, 2025 04:00 AM
Source:[NHKオンライン](https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20250226/k10014733731000.html)

**Nippon Steel (X) Leverages Merger Agreement for US Gov't Talks**
Nippon Steel (X) plans to use its current merger agreement with U.S. Steel as a foundation for discussions with the U.S. government. According to President Tadashi Imai, the agreement, which was valued at $14.9 billion, will serve as the starting point for negotiations aimed at securing government approval. Imai stated, 'The existing merger framework will be the basis for our talks with the U.S. government.' The Japanese firm is rethinking its strategy by combining equity investments with significant capital spending, highlighting the importance of these elements in its global expansion plan. Nippon Steel aims to address regulatory and political challenges head-on by engaging with key U.S. government stakeholders, including the Department of Commerce.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 02:02 AM
Source:[NASDAQ Stock Market](https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/nippon-steel-x-leverages-merger-agreement-us-govt-talks)

**Cliffs CEO Calls for Nippon Steel to Withdraw from Acquisition Process**
Cliffs CEO, Goncalves, stated that Nippon Steel should withdraw from the acquisition process, citing 'unresolvable significant national security concerns'. Cliffs had previously proposed a takeover of US Steel in 2023, but was rejected. Goncalves reiterated the company's long-standing stance that Nippon Steel's acquisition is 'certainly not going to happen'. Cliffs has resumed its consideration of acquiring US Steel after receiving a presidential order from Biden to block Nippon Steel's acquisition plan. Meanwhile, Nippon Steel has filed a lawsuit against Goncalves, alleging that he organized organized illegal activities with the USW labor union to block the acquisition in January.
Original language: ja
Publish date: February 25, 2025 10:24 PM
Source:[Yahoo!ニュース](https://news.yahoo.co.jp/articles/e210015abc399075297f09cbc8f9a313ff5c178f)

**US Steel Stock Falls as Trump Distance Himself from Nippon Steel Investment Talks**
US Steel's stock fell 1.9% on February 13, 2025, after US President Trump stated that the tariffs he implemented would save the company and that he would not support a deal where Japanese steelmaker Nippon Steel would invest in US Steel. When asked if he would still assist in negotiations between US Steel and Nippon Steel, Trump replied, 'I don't know.' Trump previously stated that Nippon Steel would not be able to acquire a majority stake in US Steel, effectively ending the current merger agreement. Trump commented, 'US Steel is now in a great position, thanks to the tariffs that I implemented, which have given the company a new path forward.' The US Steel stock price had been falling due to Trump's previous statements suggesting that the merger agreement was being abandoned.
Original language: ja
Publish date: February 13, 2025 09:11 PM
Source:[Bloomberg.com](https://www.bloomberg.co.jp/news/articles/2025-02-13/SRN193DWLU6800)

**Nippon, U.S. Steel say Biden blocked merger amid a 'sham' review**
Nippon Steel Corp. and United States Steel Corp. claim that former President Joe Biden unfairly prejudged their $14.1 billion merger and gave them no chance for feedback on a 'sham' national security review before blocking the deal. The companies say the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (Cfius) violated their due process rights by allowing 'virtually no substantive engagement' with the companies. They claim Biden blocked the merger to gain favor with union steelworkers in Pennsylvania while he was seeking re-election. The companies want the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to set aside the 'unlawful' Cfius review and Biden's order to block the deal on national security grounds. They seek a new review. 'There was no ambiguity or equivocation in the president's consistent and definitive statements disapproving the merger, starting in March 2024,' according to the filing. A former Cfius official has also come forward, stating that the review was 'predetermined, thus violating Cfius's statutory and regulatory obligations and practices.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 03, 2025 02:07 PM
Source:[crainscleveland.com](https://www.crainscleveland.com/manufacturing/us-steel-nippon-blame-politics-merger-block)

**US delays enforcement of Nippon Steel merger block**
US authorities have delayed enforcing the block on Nippon Steel Corp's acquisition of US Steel Corp, citing national security concerns. The companies, Nippon Steel and US Steel, have been given an extension until June 18, 2025, to abandon the $14.9 billion deal. The companies expressed their 'pleasure' with the extension, stating that they look forward to completing the transaction, which they believe will 'secure the best future for the American steel industry and all our stakeholders.' However, the Japanese government and business community have criticized the decision, with Japanese Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry Yoji Muto labeling it 'incomprehensible' and Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba calling for Washington to 'explain clearly' its rationale.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 12, 2025 04:00 PM
Source:[taipeitimes.com](https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/biz/archives/2025/01/13/2003830085)

**Nippon Steel-US Steel Acquisition Deal Gets Four-Month Extension**
The US Committee on Foreign Investment (CFIUS) has approved a four-month extension for Nippon Steel to withdraw from its $14.1 billion acquisition of US Steel. The original deadline of February 2 was extended to June 18, as per a request from President Joe Biden to halt the deal earlier this month. A Nippon Steel spokesperson confirmed the extension to the press. The new deadline coincides with the expected completion date of the merger. The decision was made after the two companies submitted a petition to the US Court of Appeals in Washington, arguing that CFIUS had not proven the deal's impact on national security and that President Biden's block was based on 'purely political reasons.' According to a Nikkei report, Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is preparing for a visit to the US in early February 2025 to meet with President-elect Donald Trump, where they may discuss the Nippon Steel deal.
Original language: vi
Publish date: January 12, 2025 01:02 PM
Source:[vietnamplus.vn](https://www.vietnamplus.vn/thuong-vu-nippon-steel-thau-tom-us-steel-duoc-gia-han-them-4-thang-post1007153.vnp)

**Nippon, US Steel sue Biden administration over blocked merger**
U.S. Steel and Nippon Steel sued the Biden administration over a decision to block their proposed $14 billion merger, citing election-season political considerations. The companies allege that the administration used the government review process as a pretext to reject the merger as a favor to the United Steelworkers (USW) labor union. According to the lawsuit, President Biden first announced plans to block the merger in March 2024, before the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) began its review of the national security implications of the deal. The USW has 1.2 million members, with a large concentration in the influential swing state of Pennsylvania. As Biden said, 'Without domestic steel production and domestic steel workers, our nation is less strong and less secure.' However, Nippon Steel and U.S. Steel claim that this decision was motivated by a promise made to the USW leadership, rather than genuine national security concerns.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 06, 2025 05:48 PM
Source:[abc7news.com](https://abc7news.com/post/nippon-us-steel-file-suit-after-biden-administration-blocks-15-billion-deal/15763606/)

**Nippon Steel and US Steel File Complaint Against Biden's Blockage of Merger Operation**
Nippon Steel Corporation and United States Steel Corporation (US Steel) have filed a complaint against the blockage imposed by US President Joe Biden on their merger operation. The blockage, citing national security reasons, was implemented on January 3, 2025, for a transaction valued at nearly $15 billion. In a joint statement, the companies accuse Biden of 'ignoring the Rule of Law' and 'gaining the favor of the United Steelworkers union' to 'support his political agenda' in what they describe as an 'illegal political interference in the process'. They stated, 'Today's legal actions demonstrate our continued commitment to completing the transaction.' Nippon Steel and US Steel 'remain confident that the transaction is the best path forward for US Steel's future' and 'will vigorously defend our rights to achieve this goal.'
Original language: es
Publish date: January 06, 2025 02:19 PM
Source:[notimerica.com](https://www.notimerica.com/politica/noticia-eeuu-nippon-steel-us-steel-denuncian-bloqueo-biden-operacion-compraventa-20250106141908.html)

**Nippon Steel and US Steel to Take Legal Action Against US Government Over Acquisition Block**
Nippon Steel, a Japanese steel company, and US Steel, a US steel giant, have announced that they will take legal action against the US government after President Biden issued an order to block the acquisition of US Steel by Nippon Steel. The two companies stated in a joint statement that they will take all necessary measures to protect their legal rights and confirm the fairness of the process. They criticized the US government's Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) for its 'extremely unfair' review of the acquisition plan, which they claim was based on political considerations rather than a thorough investigation. The companies emphasized that they will continue to pursue the acquisition plan, saying, 'We will never give up on conducting business in the United States.' Biden stated that the acquisition plan poses a risk to national security and the stability of the steel industry, and ordered the companies to take all necessary steps to abandon the plan within 30 days. US Steel Workers, a labor union opposed to the acquisition, welcomed the decision, saying, 'This is the right decision for our members and national security.' The acquisition plan was announced by Nippon Steel in December 2023 and was approved by US Steel in April 2024, but it has been embroiled in controversy due to political considerations. The CFIUS reviewed the plan until December 23, 2024, but failed to reach an agreement on the security risks involved, and referred the matter to Biden for a final decision. The situation is complicated by the upcoming presidential election in the US, where both the Democratic and Republican parties have expressed opposition to the acquisition. The stock price of US Steel fell by 6.5% on January 3, 2025, after Biden's announcement, reflecting market concerns about the company's financial performance and the uncertain future of the acquisition plan.
Original language: ja
Publish date: January 04, 2025 03:05 AM
Source:[読売新聞オンライン](https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/economy/20250104-OYT1T50032/)

**Biden Halts Nippon Steel's Bid: A Blow to U.S. Steel Merger | Headlines**
President Joe Biden blocked Nippon Steel's $14.9 billion purchase of U.S. Steel, citing national security concerns, after a year-long review by CFIUS. The decision may deter foreign investment in politically sensitive U.S. firms and could lead to legal challenges affecting Nippon's growth strategy. Analysts suggest that the timing, less than a year before a presidential election, heightened the risks. The Japanese government and business sectors had expressed support for the merger, but its collapse is likely to trigger a significant shift in Nippon Steel's overseas strategy.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 03, 2025 02:18 PM
Source:[Devdiscourse](https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/headlines/3214192-biden-halts-nippon-steels-bid-a-blow-to-us-steel-merger)

**Biden Blocks Nippon Steel's Acquisition of US Steel, Stock Plummets**
US President Biden has decided to block the acquisition of US Steel by Japan's Nippon Steel, causing the company's stock to plummet over 8% before the market opened on January 3. Nippon Steel has declined to comment on the decision. The acquisition has faced repeated setbacks since Nippon Steel announced its plan to acquire US Steel in late 2023. Biden has expressed his hope that US Steel be owned and operated by Americans, and former President Trump has also pledged to block the deal if he were to become president again. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) submitted its evaluation report on the acquisition to President Biden on December 24, 2024, and Biden has 15 days to decide whether to approve the deal. Nippon Steel has proposed to maintain US Steel's production capacity for 10 years after the acquisition, giving the US government the right to veto any reduction in production. However, the US Steelworkers Union has rejected this proposal, citing a lack of long-term commitment. The union has been opposed to the merger from the start. US Steel has been struggling financially, with a 12.78% decline in revenue and a 58.52% decline in profit in the third quarter of 2024. The company's stock price has also fallen behind that of its peers. Despite the controversy, Nippon Steel and US Steel remain committed to completing the deal. US Steel CEO David Burritt has said that if the sale to Nippon Steel fails, the company will close its steel plants and may relocate its headquarters out of Pittsburgh. Nippon Steel has promised to invest $3 billion in US Steel, which is crucial for maintaining competitiveness and preserving jobs. Nippon Steel has also pledged to improve US Steel's operations using its advanced production technology, and to maintain the company's name and brand, as well as its Pittsburgh headquarters and production facilities. 'We are confident that this acquisition will protect and promote the development of the US steel industry,' Nippon Steel said.
Original language: zh
Publish date: January 03, 2025 02:12 PM
Source:[东方财富网](https://finance.eastmoney.com/a/202501033287326314.html)

**US Steel Stock Drops Pre-Market On Reports Of Biden Blocking Nippon Steel Deal: Retail Sentiment Crumbles**
U.S. Steel (X) stock dropped as much as 8% in pre-market trade after reports emerged that President Joe Biden will block its acquisition by Japan's Nippon Steel, citing national security concerns. The $14.1 billion deal has faced pushback from the government and the United Steelworkers union. Sources told the Washington Post that Biden opted to kill the deal despite efforts by his senior advisers to sway him. The White House has not issued a formal statement, but both companies have indicated they will pursue legal action once the deal is formally blocked. Retail sentiment around U.S. Steel on Stocktwits has turned extremely bearish, with some investors expressing confidence that the deal will eventually get approved in court, while others say it's unlikely anyone else will want to buy U.S. Steel. 'It's unlikely that anyone other than Nippon Steel would want to buy U.S. Steel,' said one retail investor on the platform. 'Some even expressed solidarity with the decision to keep U.S. Steel American-owned,' according to reports. The collapse of the deal would represent a victory for United Steelworkers union president David McCall, who has been vocal in his opposition to the acquisition. U.S. Steel's stock has dropped more than 30% in 2024 amid the acquisition controversy.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 03, 2025 01:54 PM
Source:[Asianet News Network Pvt Ltd](https://newsable.asianetnews.com/markets/us-steel-stock-drops-pre-market-on-reports-of-biden-blocking-nippon-steel-deal-retail-sentiment-crumbles-spimah)

**Biden Set to Block Nippon-U.S. Steel Merger: A High-Stakes Economic Standoff | Politics**
U.S. President Joe Biden is poised to block Nippon Steel's $14.9-billion bid to acquire U.S. Steel, potentially ending the contentious merger plan. Despite senior advisers warning of potential diplomatic fallout with Japan, Biden's decision may come soon. Nippon Steel has offered concessions, including relocating its U.S. headquarters and giving veto power to the U.S. government over production cuts. However, the company could face penalties and a strategic overhaul if the deal collapses, with U.S. Steel shares falling 7.8% in pre-market trading after reports of the impending rejection.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 03, 2025 10:28 AM
Source:[Devdiscourse](https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3213933-biden-set-to-block-nippon-us-steel-merger-a-high-stakes-economic-standoff)

**Biden Set to Block Nippon-U.S. Steel Merger: A High-Stakes Economic Standoff**
U.S. President Joe Biden is reportedly set to block Nippon Steel's $14.9-billion bid to acquire U.S. Steel, citing national security concerns. Despite senior advisers warning of potential diplomatic fallout with Japan, Biden's decision may come soon. Nippon Steel has offered concessions, including relocating its U.S. headquarters and giving veto power to the U.S. government over production cuts. However, if the deal collapses, the company could face penalties and a strategic overhaul. U.S. Steel shares have fallen 7.8% in pre-market trading following reports of the impending rejection.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 03, 2025 10:22 AM
Source:[devdiscourse.com](https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3213933-biden-set-to-block-nippon-us-steel-merger-a-high-stakes-economic-standoff)

**Biden blocks takeover of U.S. Steel by Japan's Nippon Steel**
President Joe Biden blocked Nippon Steel's proposed $14.9 billion purchase of U.S. Steel, citing national security concerns. The deal was announced in December 2023 and had been under review for a year. Biden said, 'A strong domestically owned and operated steel industry represents an essential national security priority and is critical for resilient supply chains.' The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States had referred the decision to Biden after failing to reach consensus. Nippon Steel had offered concessions, including giving the U.S. government veto power over changes to output, but analysts say another buyer could emerge. United Steelworkers President David McCall praised Biden's decision, saying it was 'the right move for our members and our national security.' Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba had urged Biden to approve the merger, but Biden's decision may dissuade international investors from bidding for politically sensitive U.S. companies. Nippon Steel faces a $565 million penalty payment following the deal's collapse.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 03, 2025 10:18 AM
Source:[brainerddispatch.com](https://www.brainerddispatch.com/news/national/biden-blocks-takeover-of-u-s-steel-by-japans-nippon-steel)

**Biden to block US Steel sale to Japanese buyer - source**
US President Joe Biden has decided to block Nippon Steel's proposed $14.9 billion purchase of US Steel, citing concerns over the deal's impact on US national and economic security. The decision, made despite efforts by some senior advisers to approve the deal, is seen as a blow to the merger plan. Nippon Steel had offered to move its US headquarters to Pittsburgh and honour all agreements with the US Steel union, but the deal still faced opposition from the powerful United Steelworkers union and politicians. Alistair Ramsey, vice president of steel research at Rystad Energy, said blocking the deal may dissuade international investors from bidding for US companies with unionized workforces. Nippon Steel has vowed to fight the decision in the courts, but experts say it would be a difficult challenge. The collapse of the deal will prompt a major rethink of Nippon Steel's overseas-focused growth strategy, and the company faces a $565m penalty payment to US Steel.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 03, 2025 10:14 AM
Source:[RTE.ie](https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2025/0103/1488936-us-steel-deal/)

**Nippon reportedly adds 10-year guarantee to not reduce US Steel production if deal goes through**
Nippon Steel is making a final push to acquire U.S. Steel by offering a 10-year guarantee that it will not reduce production in six states, including Pennsylvania, if the deal goes through. According to The Washington Post, a document sent to the White House reveals this guarantee. President Joe Biden is set to make a decision on the multi-billion dollar merger by January 7. In a statement, Nippon Steel said the acquisition is still under review, and the closing date has been revised to the first quarter of 2025. The company hopes President Biden will conduct a 'fair and fact-based evaluation of the acquisition' during the 15-day period.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 01, 2025 01:26 PM
Source:[wtae.com](https://www.wtae.com/article/nippon-us-steel-production-guarantee/63315797)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To determine the initial probability of the US Steel/Nippon Steel merger collapsing before April 1, 2025, it's useful to look at historical data on merger failures. According to industry research, about 20% of large-scale mergers and acquisitions collapse before completion due to various reasons such as regulatory issues, financial challenges, or strategic realignments. Thus, the base rate for merger failures can be set at 20%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Regulatory Environment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Given the recent history of increased scrutiny on large mergers, particularly in the industrial sector, regulatory hurdles could impose challenges. The merger would likely receive rigorous analysis from competition authorities in the US and potentially other countries. Although it's not certain, regulatory pressures can impact the negotiation timelines or terms, thereby increasing the risk of collapse.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic Climate
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The global economic climate as of 2025 is showing moderate growth with some volatility due to fluctuating commodity prices and geopolitical factors. These economic uncertainties can influence the financing and strategic priorities of companies involved in large mergers like this one.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Strategic Alignment and Synergy Metrics
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Although synergy is a key driver for mergers, any deviation in projected synergies might lead either party to reconsider the merger's benefits. Unlike tech mergers, manufacturing companies face tangible challenges in aligning operations and cultures. Hence, potential misalignments could influence the likelihood of terminating the deal.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news that Ancora Holdings Group is urging a delay in U.S. Steel's annual meeting due to uncertainty highlights the significant internal and external challenges facing the merger. Additionally, President Trump's opposition to the merger, reiterated after the US-Japan summit, signifies strong political resistance which aligns with the initial perspective considering regulatory and political challenges. The United Steelworkers Union filing a complaint also underscores the intense domestic resistance, which is a significant factor that could lead to the collapse of the merger.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Nippon Steel remains committed to pursuing the merger, as indicated by their persistence in engaging U.S. government officials and their public statements of commitment. Furthermore, the decision by U.S. authorities to delay the final enforcement of the merger block till June suggests that there is still room for negotiation and potential resolution, which adds a degree of optimism that was not fully accounted for initially.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, corporate mergers have a significant rate of failure or abandonment before completion. According to a study by the Harvard Business Review, around 70% to 90% of mergers and acquisitions fail to achieve their intended strategic goals. However, the outright collapse prior to formal agreement consummation is less frequent. Industry-specific rates suggest that approximately 30% of proposed mergers in heavy industries, like steel, are either delayed significantly or abandoned due to financial, regulatory, or cultural reasons. This is a reasonable base rate for the probability of the merger collapsing before completion.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Regulatory Scrutiny
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Steel industry mergers can face significant regulatory hurdles, particularly related to antitrust laws, as governments monitor deals that may reduce competition or create monopolistic pressures. Such scrutiny often leads to delays or changes in the deal terms, sometimes resulting in the collapse of the merger if conditions become untenable.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Company and Cultural Synergies
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Nippon Steel and U.S. Steel come from different cultural and operational backgrounds, leading to potential integration challenges. Cultural friction between organizations has historically contributed to merger failures, particularly in international deals where differing corporate practices and employee expectations can lead to significant barriers.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic Environment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The current economic environment, marked by fluctuating steel prices and potential global recession challenges, might increase the financial risks associated with the merger. Economic instability can make a merger financially unviable or lead to reassessment of initial terms.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Previous Collaborative Efforts
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: U.S. Steel and Nippon Steel may have had prior alliances or joint ventures which establish a foundation of collaboration, reducing the likelihood of failure due to mutual understanding and previously navigated regulatory landscapes.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Multiple articles indicate strong political and regulatory resistance to the merger, including blocked attempts and legal actions. Biden's consistent blocking of the merger on national security grounds is supported by union opposition and concerns about U.S. Steel remaining domestically owned. Former President Trump's comments and the actions of influential trade unions like the USW highlight strong opposition to the deal.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite political resistance, Nippon Steel remains committed to the merger, indicated by legal challenges against Biden's blockage and offers of significant concessions. There is an extension until June 18, 2025, allowing more time for potential resolution. Continued negotiations and potential Japanese governmental support suggest some level of possible persistence.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historical data on mergers and acquisitions (M&A) typically shows a certain percentage of announced deals not reaching completion. According to studies, roughly 10% to 20% of announced M&A deals collapse before completion for various reasons such as regulatory issues, financing problems, or strategic reconsiderations. Given the size and complexity of the involved companies (US Steel and Nippon Steel) and the environment of international mergers, we can start with a base probability of 15% for the collapse of this merger.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Regulatory Scrutiny
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Large international mergers like US Steel and Nippon Steel often face increased regulatory scrutiny due to antitrust concerns. analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Nippon Steel continues to assert its commitment to the acquisition, offering significant concessions such as a 10-year guarantee on production levels and plans to negotiate further with U.S. governmental bodies. This suggests that despite setbacks, there remains a strategic focus on overcoming the challenges.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To estimate the initial probability, I will consider the historical frequency of mergers failing before completion. A study by the Federal Trade Commission indicates that approximately 10-20% of mergers and acquisitions are terminated before completion. Given that this is a significant merger between two major steel companies, I will use the upper bound and set the initial probability at 20% to reflect potential regulatory, economic, and strategic challenges often faced in such large-scale international mergers.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Weather-Related Supply Chain Disruptions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Climate and weather events can impact the industries reliant on robust supply chains, such as steel manufacturing. Disruptions in the supply chains due to severe weather events might cause financial strain or operational challenges, affecting the viability of the merger. Historical data shows weather disruptions have increased over the years, hence could contribute to an increased risk of merger collapse.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Climate Policy Shifts
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The steel industry must adapt to evolving climate policies, which may include stricter regulations and carbon emission reductions. If new policies are imposed rapidly, companies may face unexpected costs and strategic shifts that challenge the merger's feasibility. Increased probability of abrupt regulatory changes due to growing climate concerns could thus raise the risk of merger collapse.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Environmental Impact Assessments
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Mergers often require comprehensive environmental assessments, especially in industries with significant environmental footprints like steel production. Possible delays or negative assessments could lead to additional scrutiny and obstacles impacting the merger timeline or viability, thereby increasing the probability of collapse.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: There is significant political and legal pressure against the merger. Ancora, a major shareholder, is urging to delay meetings due to the uncertainty surrounding the blocked sale. Both Biden and Trump have expressed opposition to the merger on national security grounds, and the USW labor union is actively opposing the deal, filing complaints against Nippon Steel’s tactics. Legal challenges and the block by the Biden administration add further obstacles.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite political and legal challenges, Nippon Steel remains committed to the merger, emphasizing ongoing negotiations with the U.S. government and a push for legal avenues to continue the acquisition. Extensions have been given until June 18 to address the block, suggesting there is still a window for the agreement to proceed.

summary: After reviewing initial analyses and subsequent news updates, the consensus among forecasting experts is that the probability of the US Steel/Nippon Steel merger collapsing before April 1, 2025, has increased from initial estimates. Initially, experts estimated the likelihood of collapse ranging from 15% to 55%, with common factors being regulatory scrutiny, economic conditions, and political challenges. Upon reassessment in phase 2, influenced by news of significant political and union opposition, the estimated probabilities were revised upwards by most experts, generally ranging now from 45% to 65%. Factors reinforcing the likelihood include strong political resistance from both the Biden and Trump administrations, citing national security concerns, as well as active opposition from the United Steelworkers union and internal shareholder unrest. Despite Nippon Steel's continued commitment to the merger and efforts to negotiate with the U.S. government, the prevailing political and regulatory environment presents substantial challenges to the merger's completion.
